repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:  vim.lsp.util.apply_text_edits() may invalidate diagnostic
          extmarks without triggering 'textDocument/publishDiagnostics'.
Solution: Re-validate diagnostic extmarks by calling vim.diagnostic.show()
          manually after a text edit.

Fix #26296

comment_regular_data.body: Wonder if this might also fix https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25014? ðŸ¤”

Idk, it feels a bit odd to have such a diagnostic effect in a formatting function. Although I don't have super strong feelings about this solution, I suggest:
1. If we go with this approach, please add comments explaining why the diagnostic refreshes are necessary.
2. Investing in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/22598 instead, which proposes a more flexible/cleaner design.

> Idk, it feels a bit odd to have such a diagnostic effect in a formatting function.

I agree, not any weirder than [saving and restoring all the marks](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/14630) in the edited area though. Maybe `nvim_buf_set_text()` should restore (ext)marks itself, or otherwise avoid removal of the marks inside the affected area in the first place. Only splicing the marktree beyond the edited area. I investigated this first but since the diagnostics are still valid, simply calling `show()` seemed like a reasonable fix.

It would be nice if we could avoid tight coupling of formatting with diagnostic.
So far the two are only very loosely coupled. The flow is `text edits -> send changes to server -> server updates diagnostics`

Formatting also isn't the only source for text edits - any other action that edits text suffers from the same problem.
I suspect for formatting it's most noticeable because servers tend to send the full new contents, instead of just changed parts.
[conform.nvim](https://github.com/stevearc/conform.nvim) has some diff logic to account for that. By updating only the changed parts, most of the extmarks would be preserved.

Maybe @stevearc could upstream that logic? If its targeting the `apply_text_edits` function it would also have the advantage that it affects other text changes made via LSP too.

> Formatting also isn't the only source for text edits - any other action that edits text suffers from the same problem.

Like, say, autocompletion (using a certain plugin)...

> Formatting also isn't the only source for text edits - any other action that edits text suffers from the same problem.

What about calling `vim.diagnostic.show()` in `util.apply_text_edits()` then? This would make sure that diagnostics which are still valid, but were removed by `nvim_buf_set_text()` would be restored.

> By updating only the changed parts, most of the extmarks would be preserved.

Doesn't change the fact that affected regions will have their extmarks invalidated. I.e. the problem of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/26296 remains when using `'formatexpr' == v:lua.require("conform").formatexpr()`. I think something like this PR is needed regardless of whether any diff logic is upstreamed.

I think I might still not fully understand the problem. Isn't there a risk that this makes the problem worse?

For example, if you have diagnostics on (50, 0) and then you insert or remove some lines further above - either due to formatting, or maybe via a organize imports code action. Due to the extmarks, whatever was in (50, 0) would flow either up or down with the edits and might now appear in (52, 0), but the in-memory diagnostic structure still contains (50, 0) as line/col number. A new `show` call would then re-display the diagnostic in the wrong line.

Or do I get it wrong?

I think the situation you describe should go paired with a `'textDocument/publishDiagnostics'` notification, which itself would trigger `set()` and `show()`. This is only intended to restore the old diagnostics that did not change, but whose extmarks did get invalidated by `nvim_buf_set_text/lines() -> extmark_splice()`.

> I think the situation you describe should go paired with a 'textDocument/publishDiagnostics' notification, which itself would trigger set() and show()

But it can take a while until the server recomputed the new diagnostic. Many servers also have a debounce, to avoid flooding the client with diagnostics too often.
If we immediately redraw the diagnostics from the in-memory information I suspect users may start seeing flickers and have diagnostics jump from one location to another and back

> If we immediately redraw the diagnostics from the in-memory information I suspect users may start seeing flickers and have diagnostics jump from one location to another and back

Isn't that the case anyways? Extmark locations are simply invalid until we receive new diagnostics from the server. This just avoids the old diagnostics from being removed unnecessarily in the situation where we will not receive new diagnostics.

We can also question why the server does not issue `'textDocument/publishDiagnostics'` after a buffer edit through `nvim_buf_set_text/lines()`, shouldn't it? Maybe it will if we issue a `changed_lines()` for both the deletion and replacement of the buffer text in `nvim_buf_set_text/lines()`?

EDIT: don't think we can do that, those changes can be atomic (`ml_replace_buf()`).

To show what I mean. This is with this PR:

![recording](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/38700/d67f92d4-9215-4028-8d71-2c802c01a476)


See how after the formatting of a region the warning diagnostic (at the `U = M`) is in the wrong line.
I then save, which causes the server to publish new diagnostic and moves the warning to the right location.


Compare to current master:

![recording](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/38700/6613ba15-6458-4ee4-b29f-30409f9fe489)

The warnings correctly shift.

Right, I think what we want to do is only `show()` the old diagnostics in the edited region, not beyond it. Or have `nvim_buf_set_lines/text()` only splice marks beyond the edited region, not inside it.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: fix(diagnostic): show diagnostics following a text edit
